text:
I am running into situations requiring more than three variables, and the paving calculation becomes significant.

In an exploratory mode, 4 sometimes and 5 other time. The complete model has 6 (well 7, but two of them are in a fixed relationship throughout).  I thought about using very coarse pavings and examining them for locai of interest and regions of emptyness.
Then, in a way yet to be worked out, skilfully agglomerate those partially informative results -- and hone-in much more narrowly where it would be meaningful.

That's all conjecture, though it would not surprise me to find papers which explain how and why to do just that.

text: Yes that’s definitely the problem with the method.  If the models can be written as polynomials it may be possible to do something with HomotopyContinuation? I don’t know what the situation is with constraints there, though

text: I have been wondering about using Interval{Float16} or at least Interval{Float32} to do the coarse pavings as you suggest

text: currently Float16s are not fast, although I worked on a good, very fast Float8 implementation with someone somewhere sometime .. on github
